GT.content: “it gives (ça donne),” not an utterance in propositional structure of Greek-Latin grammar
GT.linkedContent: “it gives (ça donne),” not an utterance in propositional structure of Greek-Latin grammar

HERP.content: caught in ring of circle once questioning philosophy, engaged by Greek tongue > acc. Heidegger, obscurely, authoritatively, Greek tongue alone is logos
HERP.linkedContent: caught in ring of circle once questioning philosophy, engaged by Greek tongue > acc. Heidegger, obscurely, authoritatively, Greek tongue alone is logos

H.content: urgent contemporary matters [new technologies] not only bring classical structures into present, they seem to deconstruct these inheritances of themselves
H.linkedContent: urgent contemporary matters [new technologies] not only bring classical structures into present, they seem to deconstruct these inheritances of themselves

EM.content: the relevance accomplished in Hegelian metaphysics persists wherever metaphysics, our language, maintains its authority, even in pre-Hegelian systems (i.e. in Kant, figure of finitude organizes capacity to know from emergence of anthropological limit)
EM.linkedContent: the relevance accomplished in Hegelian metaphysics persists wherever metaphysics, our language, maintains its authority, even in pre-Hegelian systems (i.e. in Kant, figure of finitude organizes capacity to know from emergence of anthropological limit)

VM.content: for Levinas, classical dissymmetry of same and other feigns overturning while remaining the same, impassive beneath an algebraic substitution
VM.linkedContent: for Levinas, classical dissymmetry of same and other feigns overturning while remaining the same, impassive beneath an algebraic substitution

VM.content: to think the opposite is still complicit w/ classical alternatives [Levinas’ l’imprévisiblement-autre beyond classical opposition, hopeless?]
VM.linkedContent: to think the opposite is still complicit w/ classical alternatives [Levinas’ l’imprévisiblement-autre beyond classical opposition, hopeless?]

VM.content: Levinas drags all classical concepts into agora, they’re summoned to justify themselves in ethico-political language they didn’t always seek, must confess their violent aims
VM.linkedContent: Levinas drags all classical concepts into agora, they’re summoned to justify themselves in ethico-political language they didn’t always seek, must confess their violent aims

VM.content: deportation from its [logos’] own site toward the Site, toward spatial locality, is the metaphor congenital to philosophical logos > metaphor (before being rhetorical procedure) would be emergence of language itself
VM.linkedContent: deportation from its [logos’] own site toward the Site, toward spatial locality, is the metaphor congenital to philosophical logos > metaphor (before being rhetorical procedure) would be emergence of language itself

VM.content: all philosophies that don’t distinguish btwn thought/language are philosophies of original “finitude,” but they should be able to abandon this word “finitude,” which is forever prisoner to  classical framework
VM.linkedContent: all philosophies that don’t distinguish btwn thought/language are philosophies of original “finitude,” but they should be able to abandon this word “finitude,” which is forever prisoner to classical framework

VM.content: positive plenitude of classical infinity betrays itself in language w/ negative word “in-finite”
VM.linkedContent: positive plenitude of classical infinity betrays itself in language w/ negative word “in-finite”

VM.content: classical infinitism of Cartesian type, thought goes much further much faster than language [thought vs. body (language)?], would handle questions re: Levinas’ other by neutralizing space to liberate positive infinity
VM.linkedContent: classical infinitism of Cartesian type, thought goes much further much faster than language [thought vs. body (language)?], would handle questions re: Levinas’ other by neutralizing space to liberate positive infinity

VM.content: in this language, our only language, how can we not repeat Hegelianism > this language coming into absolute possession of itself?
VM.linkedContent: in this language, our only language, how can we not repeat Hegelianism > this language coming into absolute possession of itself?

VP.content: [re: not substantializing Husserlian “transcendental”] language never escapes analogy, is analogy through & through > classical war of language, casting metaphors against metaphors, takes place in difference > le langage garde la différence qui garde le langage

VP.content: classical subordination: sign to truth, language to being, speech to thought, writing to speech
VP.linkedContent: classical subordination: sign to truth, language to being, speech to thought, writing to speech

VP.content: for Husserl, that which is unnammeable is “absolute subjectivity,” a being of presence as substance, ousia, hypokeimenon > can name its attribute not its “absolute properties,” i.e. its substance [classical metaphysical scheme]
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, that which is unnammeable is “absolute subjectivity,” a being of presence as substance, ousia, hypokeimenon > can name its attribute not its “absolute properties,” i.e. its substance [classical metaphysical scheme]

POOF.content: “we, speakers of Latin that we are”
POOF.linkedContent: “we, speakers of Latin that we are”

WM.content: [classical idea of metaphor] “economist” theory, metaphor as general figure of speech
WM.linkedContent: [classical idea of metaphor] “economist” theory, metaphor as general figure of speech

POS.content: “everyday language” neither innocent nor neutral, language of Western metaphysics, carries w/ it considerable presuppositions

OTO.linkedContent: strict adherence to classical pedagogy (whose imperatives one can never break from once and for all) would reduce you to silence, tedium, tautology

DIF.content: trace as way out of closure of classical cause & effect (but not sufficient outside its text)

TB.content: classic circle always begins to turn once one asks about origin of languages/society

CHM.content: classical reason a doctrine of tradition, the tradition of logos (is there another tradition?)

RGE.content: slumber of reason, ruse of reason, slumber in the form of reason, vigilance of Hegelian logos (engenders monsters then puts them to sleep) > la raison veille sur un sommeil profond auquel elle est intéressée

RGE.linkedContent: can one inscribe in lexicon/syntax of a language, our language (of philosophy), that which exceeds opposition of concepts governed by this communal logic?

RGE.content: there’s only one discourse, it is significative, no getting around Hegel here

EJQB.content: that which was impossible for classical rationalists: to proceed w/in duplicity of God’s questionability > God is not truthful: accede to virtue of lie
EJQB.linkedContent: that which was impossible for classical rationalists: to proceed w/in duplicity of God’s questionability > God is not truthful: accede to virtue of lie

EJQB.content: God of classical philosophers had no need to write (never interrogated/interrupted himself)
EJQB.linkedContent: God of classical philosophers had no need to write (never interrogated/interrupted himself)

D.content: structural transcendental illusion, one surface of Soller’s square opens to “classical representative scene” > this is a necessity, no nonplace left out, so no pure origin can stand guard over stage as if derived from intactness of absolute opening: any attempt to return to l’intimité indemne et propre played out in illusion > nothing takes place but place

D.content: to describe a continuity of ruptures that doesn’t flatten along homogenous surface (present), necessary to turn to what's outside our language
D.linkedContent: to describe a continuity of ruptures that doesn’t flatten along homogenous surface (present), necessary to turn to what's outside our language

D.content: don’t dispel the uncertainty: whether mirror is classical stage or generalized space in which old theater is inscribed?
D.linkedContent: don’t dispel the uncertainty: whether mirror is classical stage or generalized space in which old theater is inscribed?

D.content: all oppositions sont détraquées (thrown out of whack) by “avoir-lieu” of mirror: each term takes over (capte) the other & excludes itself from itself
D.linkedContent: all oppositions sont détraquées (thrown out of whack) by “avoir-lieu” of mirror: each term takes over (capte) the other & excludes itself from itself

D.content: to try to resist removal of textual member from context—maintain boundary line btwn inside/outside of context > classical limits: remain protected against writing poison
D.linkedContent: to try to resist removal of textual member from context—maintain boundary line btwn inside/outside of context > classical limits: remain protected against writing poison

HST.content: classical thesis of time (monad, event of negation) lacked thought of forgiveness (until Bergson & Heidegger)
HST.linkedContent: classical thesis of time (monad, event of negation) lacked thought of forgiveness (until Bergson & Heidegger)

PPT.content: parergon of this book are ringed together by a circle [parergon are the classic ideas of art, those of Kant, Hegel, & in another respect, those of Heidegger]
PPT.linkedContent: parergon of this book are ringed together by a circle [parergon are the classic ideas of art, those of Kant, Hegel, & in another respect, those of Heidegger]

C.content: remainder is neither produced nor reproduced/represented [in Titus-Carmel’s coffins], classical thought re: remainder reduced to ashes > yet we retain at least more than one monumental proof (at least 127) of this historical operation
C.linkedContent: remainder is neither produced nor reproduced/represented [in Titus-Carmel’s coffins], classical thought re: remainder reduced to ashes > yet we retain at least more than one monumental proof (at least 127) of this historical operation

LI.content: “classical concept” as target: a tortuous, complex strategy > exploit target against itself by discovering it to be “basis” of an operation directed against itself, or discovering “in it” the cryptic reserve of something utterly different

LI.content: classically, fact has been opposed to essence (or principle) > le procès juridico-théorique that leads to an essential definition
LI.linkedContent: classically, fact has been opposed to essence (or principle) > le procès juridico-théorique that leads to an essential definition

LI.content: Derrida does not ignore the profound/classical necessity of theoretical-methodological idealizations that isolates “serious literal speech” [Donald Trump]
LI.linkedContent: Derrida does not ignore the profound/classical necessity of theoretical-methodological idealizations that isolates “serious literal speech” [Donald Trump]

LI.content: differance, iterability—not entirely words or concepts, must take classical discourse into account, accept logic of “all or nothing” > when one no longer does (via differance, mark, supplement…), must rigorously, pedagogically, explain why one changes the rules
LI.linkedContent: differance, iterability—not entirely words or concepts, must take classical discourse into account, accept logic of “all or nothing” > when one no longer does (via differance, mark, supplement…), must rigorously, pedagogically, explain why one changes the rules

LI.linkedContent: where the rigorous no longer depends on a binary logic: a more powerful discourse reinscribes “illusory” of “ideal purity” into a thought of its possibility

LI.content: structural idealism, not illusion: constitutes condition of a certain classical value called scientific truth > iterability that makes such truth possible renders it inaccessible (not illusory)
LI.linkedContent: structural idealism, not illusion: constitutes condition of a certain classical value called scientific truth > iterability that makes such truth possible renders it inaccessible (not illusory)

LI.content: Derrida, as a classical philosopher (which, it is true, he remains as well), doesn’t see a big difference btwn “just a little serious” and “not serious at all”
LI.linkedContent: Derrida, as a classical philosopher (which, it is true, he remains as well), doesn’t see a big difference btwn “just a little serious” and “not serious at all”

TN.linkedContent: to proclaim “essential originarity” of technical [as Nancy does] translates this “law” into a classical language that meets its limit here

ATM.linkedContent: doing so in a way, where the fault (la faute) [see p. 149 Derrida’s fault, failing], which consists in inscribing tout autre in empire of same, alters the same enough to absolve it of itself

EU.linkedContent: natural languages fixed, rooted, re-rooted in event of Bible translation > Luther suffices as emblem

FV.linkedContent: when literary writing occupies illustrative position: text in service of truth, to read general law in example, the most classical practice > Lacan: truth makes fiction possible

FV.content: Lacan’s highly classical interpretation of mimesis: Dichtung as detour toward truth, more truth in fiction, fiction manifests the truth [i.e. for Lacan, truth is not a fiction]
FV.linkedContent: Lacan’s highly classical interpretation of mimesis: Dichtung as detour toward truth, more truth in fiction, fiction manifests the truth [i.e. for Lacan, truth is not a fiction]
